frame_title: From Building to Breaking: Day 4 $\to$ Day 5
The Big Picture: Why Failures Matter

jargon_undefined.note: Appears on timeline as 'Flash Loan Era 2020' without definition; defined later in frame 10 but first-seen here

findings: MEDIUM: 'Flash Loan Era 2020' label appears on the timeline before flash loans are defined (frame 10). Students encountering this term for the first time will not understand it.

jargon_undefined.note: Listed as a sub-category under Human failures without definition; defined later in frame 17

findings: MEDIUM: 'Rug pulls' appears in the taxonomy diagram under Human failures without any definition or parenthetical. It is defined much later in frame 17.

MEDIUM: Frame introduces 8 distinct vulnerability types (reentrancy, integer overflow, access control, oracle manipulation, bridge vulnerabilities, consensus bugs, key management) plus 2 case studies. Heavy for a single slide.

frame_title: Vulnerable vs. Safe: How the Fix Works

findings: MEDIUM: Six-step attack sequence with specific ETH amounts, DeFi protocol names (dYdX, Uniswap), and the concept of shorting all in one frame. The shorting definition helps but the attack flow is dense.

frame_title: The Atomic Property of Flash Loans
findings: LOW: The definition of 'atomic' is repeated from frame 13 almost verbatim. Minor redundancy but acceptable for reinforcement.

jargon_undefined.note: Acronym introduced in Defense block at bottom; expanded on next slide

findings: LOW: TWAP acronym appears in the Defense block before being fully explained in the next frame. Minor since it is immediately expanded on the next slide.

jargon_undefined.note: Named as a decentralized oracle without further explanation of what Chainlink specifically is

findings: LOW: The '$2.8B lost to rug pulls' comparison 'roughly the entire GDP of a small country' is vague. A specific country name would be more concrete.

LOW: Protocol names Aave, Compound, Maker, Uniswap, Curve appear in the diagram without explanation. Students who skipped Day 4 details may not recognize them, though they are used here as representative nodes.

frame_title: Defense Patterns: Pull vs. Push Payments
From Technical Risks to Regulatory Responses

jargon_undefined.note: Mentioned in objective 3 before being defined in frame 8. Acceptable as learning objective preview.

frame_title: Why Should YOU Care About Crypto Regulation?

jargon_undefined.note: Used in the alertblock example without prior definition. Defined later in frame 16.

findings: MEDIUM: MiCA is used in the alertblock ('When MiCA took effect in the EU') without prior definition. Students will not know what MiCA is at this point. It is defined 13 frames later.
LOW: Six regulatory concepts defined in a dense table. Each concept deserves more context but the table format is efficient. Borderline cognitive load.

frame_title: How to Read Any Regulatory Framework
United States: The Big Two Regulators

findings: MEDIUM: Seven distinct agencies (FinCEN, OCC, FDIC, Federal Reserve, 50 States, plus SEC and CFTC from prior frame) presented in one slide. This is a lot of institutional detail for a BSc audience with no finance prerequisites.

frame_title: US: If Your Token Is a Security, What Are Your Options?
findings: MEDIUM: Dense frame with Reg D, Reg A+, Reg S, Reg CF, accredited investor definition, prospectus definition, and general solicitation concept. This is graduate-level securities law compressed into one slide.
LOW: Securities exemption pathways (Reg D, Reg A+, etc.) assume familiarity with IPO processes. The course promises no finance prerequisites, and these are specialized concepts.

frame_title: From US Fragmentation to EU Harmonization

prerequisite_knowledge: MiCA categories from frame 20, stablecoins from Day 4

frame_title: Singapore: Innovation Hub with Clear Rules

findings: LOW: The alertblock states 'Maximum control, full surveillance' which is a strong editorial characterization. While factually supported, it could benefit from attribution or a more neutral framing.

frame_title: Japan and South Korea: Regulated Markets
prerequisite_knowledge: Exchange concept, Mt. Gox from T5.1
DeFi concepts from Day 4, DAO concept
Smart contracts from Day 4, sanctions concept
UST/LUNA from T5.1 frame 18 and Day 4

frame_title: Case Study: FTX Collapse and Exchange Oversight
Case Study Synthesis: What Do These Cases Teach Us?

jargon_undefined.note: The concept 'the challenge of making sure the people who manage an organization actually serve the members interests' alludes to the fiduciary duty concept but does not name or define it explicitly

findings: LOW: The prerequisites list 'DeFi protocol basics (from T5.2)' but T5.2 covers regulatory landscapes, not DeFi protocol basics. DeFi protocol basics are from Day 4. Minor mislabel.

prerequisite_knowledge: Square root, token voting from frame 6
findings: MEDIUM: Frame covers quadratic voting formula, three worked examples, impact analysis, advantages, AND the Sybil attack vulnerability with its own numeric example. This is a lot of mathematical content for a single frame in a no-math-prerequisites course.
MEDIUM: Frame includes a decay factor formula, a four-day worked example with arithmetic, a pgfplots graph, and tradeoff analysis. Dense for a BSc audience with no math prerequisites.

prerequisite_knowledge: Flash loans from T5.1, governance tokens from frame 5
findings: LOW: Frame covers the flash loan governance attack sequence (4 steps), the Beanstalk case study (4 data points), and five additional attack vectors with descriptions. Dense but attack vectors are ranked by prevalence which aids comprehension.

prerequisite_knowledge: Flash loans from T5.1, governance attacks from frame 16

jargon_undefined.note: '67% quorum' appears in step 3 of the attack diagram without prior definition. Quorum is defined later in frame 21.

findings: MEDIUM: '67% quorum' appears in the Beanstalk attack diagram (step 3) without prior definition of what quorum means. The term is defined 4 frames later in frame 21.

prerequisite_knowledge: Flash loan attacks from T5.1, governance attacks from frame 16

findings: LOW: Quorum is defined here at frame 21, but was already used without definition in frame 17 (Beanstalk case study: '67% quorum'). Moving this definition earlier or adding a parenthetical in frame 17 would improve flow.

frame_title: How a DAO Proposal Actually Works
"Code is Law" vs. Rule of Law

findings: LOW: 'Pareto distributions' and 'Gini coefficient' in Exercise 1 are statistical concepts not previously introduced. The course promises no math prerequisites.

LOW: Four DAO examples (MakerDAO, Uniswap, Compound, Aave) presented as bullet lists without motivation for why these four were chosen or what makes each distinctive. Risk of becoming an unmotivated list.

frame_title: Application: The Future of DAO Governance
What's Next: Topic 5.4 -- Privacy and Financial Inclusion

findings: MEDIUM: Frame introduces ring signatures, CoinJoin, and tumbling/mixing services all at once. Each is a distinct cryptographic concept. Three privacy techniques in one frame is dense for a no-prerequisites audience.

MEDIUM: Frame introduces RingCT, Bulletproofs (range proofs), zk-SNARKs, zk-STARKs, and trusted setup concepts in a single slide. Five distinct cryptographic concepts is very dense, even with analogies.
LOW: The password analogy and zk-SNARKs/zk-STARKs/Bulletproofs descriptions are largely repeated from frame 10. Acceptable for reinforcement but noticeable overlap.

frame_title: Privacy Coin Deep Dive: Monero's Privacy Stack
findings: LOW: Ring signatures and stealth address analogies are repeated from frames 8-9. This is the third time these analogies appear. While reinforcement is valuable, it adds slide density.

prerequisite_knowledge: Smart contracts from Day 4, OFAC from T5.2
findings: LOW: Tornado Cash case study is also covered in T5.2 frame 31. The T5.4 version adds privacy-technology context but the core facts overlap significantly. Cross-referencing T5.2 would reduce repetition.

MEDIUM: The frame title 'The Ultimate Surveillance Tool?' uses a leading/rhetorical framing that may come across as one-sided before presenting evidence. The content itself is balanced, but the title sets a negative tone.

MEDIUM: Seven CBDC capabilities listed (transaction visibility, programmable restrictions, auto tax, demurrage, geographic restrictions, social credit, remote freezing) plus China's e-CNY case study. Very dense for one frame.

frame_title: Case Study: El Salvador Bitcoin Experiment

prerequisite_knowledge: ZK proofs from frames 10-11, OFAC from T5.2
KYC from T5.2, ZK proofs from frames 10-11

frame_title: Day 5 Arc: From Failures to Values
Additional Content: The Political Nature of Money

prerequisite_knowledge: Privacy-transparency spectrum from frame 5, regulation from T5.2
findings: MEDIUM: Five jurisdictions (EU, US, China, India, Africa) each with multiple bullet points crammed into one frame. This is essentially a regulatory comparison slide that covers more ground than some entire T5.2 frames.

frame_title: Concept Map: Privacy, Surveillance, and Inclusion
What's Next: Day 6 -- Convergence and the Future
